title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act is titled the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002." It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act defines the Corporation as The Howard Hughes Corporation and Red Rock as the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area in Nevada. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area was designated for protection in the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990. The term "Red Rock Map" refers to the map depicting boundary modifications, dated July 1, 2002. The term "Secretary" in this context refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds Red Rock to be a significant natural resource that must be protected and enhanced for future generations. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 aimed to protect and enhance Red Rock. The Corporation owns much of the private land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is involved in development efforts. The Corporation owns a significant portion of private land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is developing a large-scale master-planned community. This includes 1,071 acres of high-ground lands at the eastern edge of Red Rock, which have not been acquired by the United States yet. The protection of this high-ground acreage is crucial for preserving the western Las Vegas Valley view-shed. The Corporation has volunteered to forgo development of these lands. The Corporation owns high-ground lands on Red Rock's eastern boundary and proposes transferring them to the United States to protect and expand Red Rock. The Act aims to exchange lands between the United States and the Corporation to preserve Red Rock and expand its boundaries. The Corporation aims to protect and expand Red Rock by transferring high-ground lands to the United States. This aligns with the goals of the Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act and the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act. The Corporation aims to protect and expand Red Rock by transferring high-ground lands to the United States, in alignment with the goals of the Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act and the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act. SEC. 4. RED ROCK LAND EXCHANGE. The Corporation offers to convey approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States, depicted on the Red Rock Map. The Secretary will accept the offer and make conveyances within 90 days, including transferring approximately 998 acres of Federal lands to the Corporation and approximately 1,221 acres to Clark County, Nevada. The Red Rock Map depicts Federal lands for exchange and Clark County Park. Title to private and Federal property will be conveyed simultaneously. The Secretary will keep the Red Rock Map for public inspection in Nevada. The Bureau of Land Management in Nevada and the State Office of the Bureau in Reno are involved in the conveyance of property. The Secretary requires the Corporation to be responsible for hazardous materials removal and remediation. Additionally, a survey must be provided within 90 days of the offer. The Corporation must provide a metes and bounds survey of the common boundary between the parcels of land to be conveyed within 90 days of the offer. The lands transferred to Clark County must be held in perpetuity for use as a public park or regional trail system. The lands transferred to Clark County must be held in perpetuity for use as a public park or regional trail system, and if the County attempts to transfer or use the lands inconsistently, they shall revert to the United States. SEC. 5. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LANDS. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary will administer the lands shown on the Red Rock Map as "Flood Control Detention Basin Lands" as part of Red Rock, excluding those used for the Corps of Engineers R-4 Detention Basin, in accordance with relevant laws. Upon acquisition of lands under this Act, the Secretary will make boundary adjustments as necessary. Upon acquisition of lands under this Act, the Secretary will administer them as part of Red Rock in accordance with relevant laws and create new maps reflecting boundary adjustments. The Secretary will administer acquired lands under this Act as part of Red Rock, create new maps reflecting boundary adjustments, and make them available for review at designated offices. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to include additional areas in the conservation area. The Secretary will administer acquired lands under this Act as part of Red Rock and create new maps reflecting boundary adjustments. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to include additional areas in the conservation area. General provisions are outlined in Section 6. The Secretary will review a specific appraisal and any difference in values will be reimbursed by the Corporation. The land exchange will respect valid existing rights, and parties receiving property will assume the rights and obligations of the conveying party. The conveyances under this Act will transfer rights and obligations of the conveying party regarding leases, permits, and other existing rights. Parties can correct technical errors in the Red Rock Map. The Secretary will withdraw Federal lands acquired under this Act from public land and mining laws, preserving valid existing rights. The Secretary will withdraw Federal lands acquired under this Act and those already owned by the United States within the Red Rock National Conservation Area boundaries, preserving valid existing rights. Passed the House of Representatives on October 1, 2002. Clerk attests.
